0:
config:
  bind: 0.0.0.0:{{ .Values.service.main.ports.main.port }}
  onlineMode: true
  debug: true
  query:
    enabled: true
    port: {{ .Values.service.main.ports.query.port }}
    showPlugins: false
  lite:
    enabled: true
    routes:
      - host: [modpack.${DOMAIN_0}]
        backend: minecraft-modpack-minecraft-java.minecraft.svc.cluster.local:25565
        cachePingTTL: -1s
        fallback:
          motd: |
            §cModpack server is offline.
            §eCheck back later!
          version:
            name: '§cTry again later!'
            protocol: -1
          favicon: /icons/server-icon.png
      - host: [tcpshield.${DOMAIN_0}, ${DOMAIN_0}]
        backend: minecraft-vanilla-minecraft-java.minecraft.svc.cluster.local:25565
        cachePingTTL: -1s
        fallback:
          motd: |
            §cModpack server is offline.
            §eCheck back later!
          version:
            name: '§cTry again later!'
            protocol: -1
          favicon: /icons/server-icon.png

/hr/quay.io-metallb-chart-metallb.title: metallb helm release
/hr/quay.io-metallb-chart-metallb.name: metallb
/hr/quay.io-metallb-chart-metallb.doc: metallb is a load-balancer implementation for Kubernetes, allowing you to create services with type: LoadBalancer. With BGP, you can setup IP ranges in your network that get assigned to k8s services. You can use IP addresses that are assigned to you, and share them amongst services.

/hr/ghcr.io-home-operations-charts-mirro.title: metallb helm release
/hr/ghcr.io-home-operations-charts-mirro.name: metallb
/hr/ghcr.io-home-operations-charts-mirro.doc: metallb is a load-balancer implementation for Kubernetes, allowing you to create services with type: LoadBalancer. With BGP, you can setup IP ranges in your network that get assigned to k8s services. You can use IP addresses that are assigned to you, and share them amongst services.

0:
trap 'exit' INT TERM
while [ 1 ]; do
  sleep 600 &
  wait $!
done
